FacilityName: Cargill Meat Solutions Corp - Fort Worth
SafetyInspectionBy: Texas Department of State Health Services

_prev_prog_3.Description: Cargill Meat Solutions has implemented a Process Safety Management Program in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.119.  Program elements include 3 year audits, process hazard analysis, management of change procedures, standard operating procedures, mechanical integrity, and employee training.  The facility has implemented an Emergency Action Plan that includes response actions the facility will take in the unlikely event of an ammonia release.  Employee training and emergency action drills are conducted.  The system is shutdown every night after production ends and is restarted the next morning.  Trained operators are at the facility when the system is in operation.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Cargill Meat Solutions - Fort Worth primary business is processing wholesale distribution of meat products for human consumption. The facility operates an ammonia refrigeration system as part of the process to keep products and raw materials fresh. 40 CFR 68.130 lists anhydrous ammonia as a hazardous chemical subject to RMP regulation with a threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs. The refrigeration system inventory exceeds the 10,000 lb. threshold.  Ammonia is recirculated in the system as a liquid and gas depending on system operating pressures and temperatures.  



The RMP was modified in March 2016 due to the addition of a new vessel, which increased the total onsite inventory of ammonia.



Facility release modeling was performed using EPA's modeling program RMP*Comp. The worst-case scenario is based on the High Pressure Receiver as that vessel could potentially hold the largest quantity of ammonia. No passive or administrative controls were considered for the release scenario. 



The alternate release scenario is based on a pipe rupture on the roof. Other alternate cases were considered, including vessel overfilling, over pressurization scenarios, pipe ruptures and material handling and transfer hoses. 



The facility has developed and implemented a Process Safety Management Program (PSM) in accordance with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119.  The facility's PSM program includes provisions for process hazard analyses, training, standard operating procedures, management of change, pre-start up safety reviews, safe work practices, inspections, testing, maintenance, compliance audits, and contractor qualifications. All significant changes to the system are reviewed in accordance with the PSM/ RMP management of change provisions in the facility's plan. Qualified outside contractors are used for construction and major repairs or modifications to the system. The facility has an emergency action plan in place and conducts p

eriodic response drills and coordinates with the local fire department and LEPC. The facility is committed to continually improving safety through program implementation and execution. The facility has never experienced a release incident that meets the EPA's 5 Year Accident Reporting criteria involving ammonia that resulted in any on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or that resulted in any offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. 



The system is equipped with a series of redundant failsafe devices, sensors, and overrides. In the event a malfunction occurs that could result in an ammonia release, these protective devices shut the system down.
